zuul_registry/storage.py.message: The uuids are... uuids.  :)  We generate them using uuid4.hex() and give them to the client when it starts an upload, so should be unique per upload globally.

Won't this uuid be the same for both racing uploads? And if so wouldn't this end up deleting the objects for the other thread too?

Looking at the webserver router code the uuid appears to be client supplied, but I'm not sure if we expect clients to generate the uuid deterministically based on the content or if it is random.

In the swift case I believe two different writers may still believe they have successfully locked here due to eventual consistency of the data in swift.

It might be better to force the local filesystem to be used for these locks instead as that should be far more consistent. The downside to that is we can't operate multiple registries against the same backend.

Operating multiple registry servers with no shared state other than the backing store is still a goal here, so I'd rather make the algorithm better if we think we need to.  This is not perfect, but we've significantly reduced the race window.

roles/bindep/tasks/main.yaml.message:
I think we want to use include_tasks here (and for all of the ones in this file)

import_tasks is static, so it imports the tasks into the playbook at compile time. include_tasks is dynamic, it includes the tasks at runtime. This means that if we use include_tasks with these when conditions, we won't even include the tasks (which is where we get that nice behavior of not showing the subtasks as skipped) If we use import, each task in the included file will have the when applied and will be skipped (which makes for messy log)

3 questions:
1. the previous version of debian-isogen accepted BUILDER_CONFIG that contained cloud-init settings. maybe I don't understand something, but I don't see the place where it can be passed now. how will we pass this params now?
2. the previous image built everything from the freshest upstream. now when we have all these stages, it will be necessary to rebuilt the bunch of them?
3. if you're making another approach, why don't you make it in a separate directory? airshipctl has an ability to use an arbitrary image. once your image start working - we can deprecate the current debian-isogen...

yeah - this version takes approx 15 seconds rather than 20 mins to run, but also I see a real advantage in having a known good base to deploy from - as it stands the current approach is not suitable for production uses as it is not readable - when this gets closer to the finish line we can discuss if we want to support both approaches moving forward

right, I understand that this will save time.. because the current version runs 20 mins.. I agree with that it should be reduced. the only concern is that the current version produces always the freshest iso :) in your approach - it will be based on whatever we have the docker image. 

My point is:
I just think we want to have both images for now: the current will generate the latest; + your image - we'll need to rebuild them to maintain the freshest content... 
That's why it would be good to do it in separate dir...

this is just a wip at this point - the end interface will be 1-1 with the current approach. The major change will be that airshipctl will only be responsible for building the final iso with injected cloud-init, rather than the full rootfs/squash filesystem.

Hmm, you should probably be running this so. Here's what you need to do, if you want to test that.

1. Deploy DevStack All-In-One
2. Create a new flavor that will have a NUMA topology. For example (this is from memory so it might have typos):

    openstack flavor create --vcpu 2 --disk 0 --ram 1024 test.pinned
    openstack flavor set --property hw:numa_nodes=2

3. Start watching logs for all nova services using the below command. Be sure to do this in another terminal:

    journalctl --follow -a --unit devstack@n-*

I don't think we can do that. We really have to add new conditions to handle the 'virtio-scsi' case.

- virtio-blk is using for each disk, one PCI slot. Since there is a limit of 32 slots per machine (For Q35 it's different) and some of them are already used in our default guest configuration for networking devices, memory balloon device, USB controller...  My thinking is we should probably keep the limit of 26.

- For virtio-scsi it's different, we have one controller that is using one PCI slot. Nova currently does not support to have more virtio-scsi controller. One controller can have 256 targets and each target supports 1 to 2^14 logical device (LUN). So it's about 4194304, which does not really make sense. Limiting it to 128 or perhaps the number of targets seems good.

- For the native QEMU scsi implementation I think a target can only handle one LUN, meaning 256 devices.

mtce/src/scripts/wipedisk.message: I seem to recall that in some error cases the "ceph -s" command can hang for quite some time before it returns. If that happens, is it going to cause a problem for the caller of the wipedisk script?

I still think it's safer to put this fix under wipedisk, rather than puppet. Wipedisk has two uses (upgrade and reinstall), while puppet is called very often. So putting this in puppet may make this bug harder to test, as well as more prone to encounter corner cases.

I agree that it would be unlikely. One case might be in the initial config of a system - if controller-0 and controller-1 were installed, but something went wrong with the controller-1 configuration and the user wanted to re-install it.

The mtcClient ack's the wipedisk command before executing it but starts a failsafe sysreq reboot thread that will fire 60 seconds after the wipedisk command is executed. If the wipedisk does not complete in 60 seconds then it is interrupted by a reboot.

If this is a potential problem then we may need to extend the failsafe reset beyond 60 seconds. 

There is a mtc.conf config file option 'failsafe_shutdown_delay = 120' and the delay for wipedisk failsafe reboot is half that ; thus 60 seconds.
I think this might happen when one (or maybe two) of the monitors are down.
I still think it's better in puppet. But this solution seems safe enough.

I found out the "ceph-disk list" command doesn't actually need the ceph cluster to be operational for it to work.

So now, instead of checking if ceph is operational, we just call the "ceph-disk list" command directly and parse the output. While the call to this command finishes very fast (under 2 seconds, even if ceph is not operational), i did wrap it in a timeout command just in case.

Instead of trying to do this in the wipedisk, can we do this sometime before the first unlock after a reinstall? Maybe the puppet code could wipe the journal if INITIAL_CONFIG_COMPLETE_FLAG isn't present. The puppet manifest should be able to compute the journal disk, it wouldn't need to query ceph.

During my testing, I haven't seen such an issue occurring, but I cannot guarantee that it will never happen. 

The problem is identifying the journal partitions/disks on the current host. Querying ceph is the most obvious solution to this.

I will run some tests to simulate hanged commands using sleep commands in this script to see if any timeouts actually happen in the caller.

I have tried with 1 monitor down on a 2+2 setup and it seems fine. 

Under normal circumstances, two monitors cannot be down and at that point ceph is not operational and that is a much more serious problem.

I will test with adding a timeout to the ceph command, one which doesn't impact normal operation, but also would take into consideration abnormal scenarios with ceph.
Do we know why this isn't an issue during upgrades?

No, but it wasn't a thorough investigation of why it isn't reproducible during upgrades. But if we find evidence that it can be reproduced during upgrades, we can just remote the check in the for upgrades and fix that as well.

nit: Starlingx components
What is the difference between /opt/platform/extra and the existing /opt/extension filesystem? Who will be using each? Just curious why we are adding another.

To my knowledge, /opt/extension contains 3rd party plugins that are loosely coupled to the starlingx configuration while /opt/platform has stx platform related configuration & data.
The /opt/extension folder is also managed on a separate filesystem with a default size of 1GB.
I remember we tried once to use it and the conclusion was that we shouldn't use it (Brent was on that meeting).

The problem is that, from /opt/platform we don't back up and restore any folder so, the new folder role is to ease the b&r for developers so that they don't have to make changes for trivial platform configuration files complicating the B&R code and opening a door to potential issues. These files are available early on and can be used as part of the bootstrap process, if desired.

We hurried up its implementation after a discussion with Chris Friesen as, for his feature, he needs a place to store platform data that is backed up and restored.

Btw, the name and the location of the folder is TBD, my proposal was /opt/platform/extra.

This is currently passed directly through to 'keystoneauth1.session.Session' and you're trying to maintain that pattern they are using. However, that pattern is confusing because the option can be a boolean, a string, or none [1]. Instead of copying this pattern, how about you add a new parameter here? Something like 'verify_ssl_path', which is a 'StrOpt' that defaults to None. If 'verify_ssl' is False, 'verify_ssl_path' would be ignored. If 'verify_ssl' is True, 'verify_ssl_path' will be used if available. You could call 'Session' like so:

  sess = session.Session(
      auth=auth,
      verify=verify_ssl and verify_ssl_path or verify_ssl,
  )

Which I think is correct since a value of None (which would happen if 'verify_ssl=True' and 'verify_ssl_path=None') should indicate "for requests to attempt to locate and use certificates" [2]

doc/source/configuration/shared-file-sys.message:
We have a framework for this sort of thing - adding this in the documentation may be insufficient. Consider a cloud with EMC Unity and Vendor XYZ storage:

a user creates two shares of 2 GB each - assume one each on each of the backends - when they mount these shares, they'll see that one of the shares is 2GB and the other is 3GB


https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/src/commit/fd23a6387c92b288a4a5f64a3e0190895e14f85f/manila/share/drivers/hitachi/hsp/driver.py#L365-L366

I see. While this behavior can be consistent in a cloud environment with *only* Unity storage, it will be inconsistent in an environment with heterogeneous backends.  

Is there any way you can make this share size inflation optional? 

Possibly by means of a configuration option in the Unity backend section that determines whether the default driver filter function that I suggested earlier will be reported to the scheduler or not. 

So, by default Unity could report the default filter function, but, administrators will have a way to disable that and allow inflating share sizes if they are less than 2GB.
Hi Yong, any update on this?

This is the limitation of Unity, the minimum size of file system is 3GB even though Unity has enough space, it can't be fixed from driver side, now the workaround is supplementing it to 3GB.
The purpose of updating this doc is to note end uses of this limitation.

Hi, 

Yes, I understand that this is a limitation in the Unity backend that the Unity driver cannot circumvent. I am asking you to take a look at the "default filter function" feature provided by manila's filter scheduler. 

See an example usage in this link: https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/src/commit/fd23a6387c92b288a4a5f64a3e0190895e14f85f/manila/share/drivers/hitachi/hsp/driver.py#L365-L366


If you implement that method in your driver, the manila scheduler will automatically disallow shares smaller than 3GB from being scheduled to your driver. 

This is the way we can ensure uniformity and compatibility amongst the different backends and their capablities.

suggest adding for completeness sake:

 However, this value will be changed to True in a future release to
 ensure compliance with design expectations in Manila. So we 
  recommend always setting this option in your deployment to True
 or False per your desired behavior.


What do you think?
Updated, thanks for the comments, Goutham.

 upgrade:
     - |
       A new configuration option called ``report_default_filter_function`` has been

tacker/tests/unit/common/test_csar_utils.message: Is this test really needed even we already have test_load_csar_data_with_artifacts_and_without_sw_image_data?

This test is needed because depending on the type of artifact (short or extended) it's checking whether sw_image_data properties exists in VDU.

In test_load_csar_data_with_artifacts_and_without_sw_image_data test, artifact is defined in extended notation format whereas in this test, it is defined in short notation format.

I prefer modifying csar_with_multiple_sw_image_data.zip instead of adding this test. tosca_with_vdus.yaml in csar_with_multiple_sw_image_data.zip should include both short notation and extended notation of sw_image.

I cannot image a probable case of future development we should have these 2 tests. One possibility is someone wrongly deletes csar_utils.py line 218. In this case, this test fails but test_csar_with_multiple_sw_image_data passes. However, test_load_csar_with_artifacts_short_notation_without_sw_image_data also fails and we can detects the wrong change.

WDYT?

If there are any changes to csar_utils.py in future like you have mentioned at line 218, this test should fail and someone will need to fix it.

IMO, this tests has specific purpose so it should be retained.

I think you want to keep the test csar.zip files to as minimum as possible.

In csar_with_multiple_sw_image_data.zip, it's checking if there are two artifacts  of type "tosca.artifacts.nfv.SwImage" defined in extended notation format whereas in this test, it's checking one is defined in short notation and another in extended notation. So test data wise I think it's ok to keep the test as is.

In fact, there is one test missing where multiple artifacts are specified in short notation format in which case it will also raise the same error.

However, according to [2], the timeout is configurable, although in that case ceph admin who changes the timeout bears the responsibility if watcher doesn't timeout in time. Why a workaround? It seems like workarounds has become abused for anything and everything.

If it's a legitimate tunable, then don't put it into workarounds. Workarounds are supposed fo be for things like "some distro libvirt libraries haven't been updated to account for bug X so add a timer or flag or something to allow WORKINGAROUND that thing for the time being."

Agree that if it's tunable on the ceph side, it needs to be tunable on the nova side, unless there is some way we can discover what the ceph tunable is and calculate 2*$ceph value or something.

Is this test going to take 30 seconds to run? If so, can we condense it to be faster by using self.flags() to set the tunables lower at the beginning?

Our gate runs take a lot of time and lots of 30 seconds added together makes the time significant.

Another thing I was thinking is you could do a different test instead of this one where it just verifies that after setting self.flags() for the tunables that the expected values are passed to a mocked FixedIntervalLoopingCall start and _cleanup_vol.
